TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
 MULTI LUMEN - START [**2169-11-22**] 03:45 AM
   Vent settings were changed to Pressure support [**1-13**] and tolerating well
   ECHO this AM
   ERCP today
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Vancomycin - [**2169-11-22**] 06:30 AM
   Infusions:

   Midazolam (Versed) - 3 mg/hour
   Fentanyl - 50 mcg/hour
   Other ICU medications:

   Review of systems:
   Flowsheet Data as of  [**2169-11-22**] 08:04 AM

   Tmax: 38.2
C (100.8

C (100.8

   BP: 94/51(62) {86/49(58) - 94/51(149)} mmHg

   PEEP: 5 cmH2O
   FiO2: 40%
   RSBI: 79
   PIP: 17 cmH2O
   SpO2: 100%
   ABG: 7.31/37/133//-6
   Ve: 9.3 L/min
   PaO2 / FiO2: 332
   Physical Examination
   General: Intubated, sedated, not responsive
   HEENT: PERRL, MMM, ETT in place
   Neck: RIJ in place
   Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, ronchi
   CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops
   Abdomen:  soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, no
   rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly
   Ext: warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no edema
   Skin: somewhat jaundiced
   Labs / Radiology
        [image002.jpg]
                            [**2169-11-22**]  02:51 AM
                            [**2169-11-22**]  04:57 AM
   TCO2
   18
   20
   Other labs: Lactic Acid:2.4 mmol/L
   Assessment and Plan
   85yo F with a h/o choledocholithiasis, HTN, renal CA, and dementia who
   presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory
   failure and septic shock.
   .
   # Dyspnea/respiratory failure:
   Likely tachypnea secondary to metabolic acidosis; pt was tiring out
   trying to compensate by respiratory means
   Has been having recently worsening dyspnea on exertion, stable
   orthopnea. Became acutely SOB requiring intubation in the ED. Repeat
   CXR shows increased bilateral opacities suggesting pulmonary edema.
   Heart failure is possible with her BNP elevation and history of
   orthopnea, although she has no known heart failure. Influenza another
   possibility, though less likely, given concurrent fever and dry cough.
   CXR was not concerning for pneumonia or fluid overload.  Consider also
   ischemia given report of chest pain, although EKG reportedly negative
   and cardiac markers negative x2, so not likely ACS. ABG shows good
   oxygenation and patient has been switched to PSV 10/5 with FiO2 40%.
   PE less likely
   - Cont PSV for now and wean as tolerated
   - R/o influenza
   - f/u w TTE from this morning
   .
   # Septic shock:
   Bandemia and lactate improving, still febrile and requiring pressors.
   Sepsis likely secondary to biliary source given CBD dilation with
   sludge and obstructive LFTs in setting on known choledocholithiasis. No
   other source of infection found.
   - Cont broad spectrum abx with vancomycin and pip-tazo
   - ERCP today for biliary drainage
   - Trend CBC/diff, lactate, LFTs
   - Follow up blood cx , urine cx
   - Cont IVF to keep CVP 10-12 mmHg and good UOP
   - Wean norepinephrine as tolerated by MAP >= 65 mmHg
   - Check ScvO2
   .
    # Anion gap acidosis:
   Most likely lactic acidosis secondary to sepsis.  Also has a non-gap
   acidosis, likely from chronic diarrhea.  Gap acidosis improving with
   IVF.
   - Cont IVF per sepsis protocol
   - trend lactate
   # ARF: Likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion
   secondary to vomiting and diarrhea. Baseline creatinine 1.2-1.4.
   - IVFs for CVP 10-12
   - f/u Urine lytes
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Trend renal function
   .
   #Thrombocytopenia
   Likely secondary to sepsis.
   - send DIC labs
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2169-11-22**] 03:45 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2169-11-22**] 03:45 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  pneumoboots, subq heparin
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:  bundle
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:  Husband
   [**Name (NI) 156**] status: Full (Presumed)
 need to confirm w husband
   Disposition:
   ------ Protected Section ------
   MICU ATTENDING PROGRESS NOTE
   I saw and examined the patient and was physically present with the ICU
   team for the key portions of the services provided. I agree with the
   resident note, including the assessment and plan. I would emphasize and
   add the following points: 85F a w/ renal ca, dementia,
   choledocolithiasis presents with n/v X 2 days, diarrhea, dyspnea, Fever
   100.9.  In ED CXR clear initially but intubated for ? evolving
   infiltrates and resp distress. RIJ CVL placed for hypotension with IVF
   given, levophed then started. Received vanco/zosyn  Labs concerning for
   biliary sepsis with t bili 9.9, transaminitis, AGMA, lactate 4.5, 18%
   bandemia and cr 2.6.  RUQ with dil cbd, sludge with ERCP consulted and
   plan for ERCP in am today.
   PE: BP: 90/50  HR90  RR 19  T: 100.8  98% ACV--> PS 12/5 40% Intubated,
   sedated, jaundiced, perrla, CTA, RR, soft + BS, non T at ruq, no edema
   LABS: wbc 25 (4.8), 19-->0 bands, hct 31.6, plt 93 (140), na 137, cr
   2.4 (2.6), lactate 2.4 (4.5), t bili 6.4 (9.9), ast/alt decreasing, inr
   1.3, 7.31/37/133, trop 0.02, BNP 5600, u/a neg
   ECG with NSR TWI 3, v1. no ST changes
   Imaging reviewed: cxr appears rotated, pulm vascular fullness, no focal
   infiltrate though would watch r mid zone for possible evolving asp pna
   A/P: Sepsis appears from biliary source/cholangitis, c/b arf and resp
   failure.  Resp failure does not appear [**3-13**] primary lung process, as CXR
   is rather unimpressive, but suspect in setting of met acidosis she
   fatigued. There is a component of mild demand ischemia by trop without
   frank ecg changes.  Agree with plan to manage biliary sepsis with broad
   antibx (vanco, zosyn for now f/u cx data), plan for ercp today to
   relieve obstruction.  She does not appear fully tanked from volume
   standpoint.  Will continue aggressive IVF (LR given NG as well as AGMA)
   for cvp > 10, weaning pressor off, following u/o, trending lactate,
   lfts, a/l.  Will continue current vent support as she is oxygenating
   well and appears comfortable on PS. Follow abgs closely for signs of
   fatigue noting her continued met acidosis. Evidence of mild demand
   ischemia in setting of septic picture--trop are  flat and without
   progressive ecg changes.  Volume may be an issue in setting of
   extubation.  TTE will be helpful. . Her ARF likely [**3-13**] vol repletion
   from sepsis, n/v and diarrhea.  Aggressive fluids as above, send urine
   lytes. Thrombocytopenia likely in part dilutional and related to
   sepsis, also concerning for DIC. Send dic panel. Low suspicion for
   HIT.  ICU prophy. Consider a-line placement if unable to wean off
   pressor. Remainder of plan as outlined in resident note. Need to
   confirm code status w/ family.
   Patient is critically ill
   Total time: 55 min.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) 143**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 144**], MD
   on:[**2169-11-22**] 02:11 PM ------

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia, who presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock.

The patient's condition is critical, and several potential medical complications can arise. These include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is being managed with pressure support ventilation (PSV) and a FiO2 of 40%. However, there is a risk of respiratory failure due to her underlying lung disease, sepsis, and acidosis.
2. Sepsis: The patient has septic shock due to biliary sepsis, and there is a risk of further deterioration if the sepsis is not effectively managed.
3. Anion gap acidosis: The patient has anion gap acidosis, which is likely due to lactic acidosis secondary to sepsis and non-gap acidosis due to chronic diarrhea. There is a risk of further acidosis if the underlying causes are not addressed.
4. Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient has ARF, which is likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion. There is a risk of further kidney injury if the patient's volume status is not properly managed.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia, which is likely secondary to sepsis. There is a risk of bleeding if the patient's platelet count does not improve.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of hypertension and renal cancer, which increases her risk of cardiac complications. There is a risk of cardiac failure, arrhythmias, and ischemia if the patient's cardiac status is not properly monitored.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of diarrhea and vomiting, which increases her risk of gastrointestinal complications such as perforation, bleeding, and sepsis.
8. Infection: The patient has a risk of developing further infections, particularly in the respiratory and urinary tracts, due to her immunocompromised state.
9. Fluid overload: The patient is receiving aggressive fluid resuscitation, which increases her risk of fluid overload and pulmonary edema.
10. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular status is unstable, and there is a risk of further deterioration if her blood pressure and cardiac output are not properly managed.

To mitigate these risks, the patient's care plan should include:

1. Aggressive management of sepsis with broad-spectrum antibiotics and fluids.
2. Close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status, including frequent ABG measurements and ventilator settings.
3. Aggressive fluid resuscitation to maintain a CVP of 10-12 mmHg and good urine output.
4. Monitoring of the patient's cardiac status, including frequent ECG measurements and cardiac enzyme levels.
5. Close monitoring of the patient's gastrointestinal status, including frequent bowel movements and abdominal examination.
6. Aggressive management of the patient's acidosis, including administration of bicarbonate and correction of underlying causes.
7. Close monitoring of the patient's platelet count and platelet transfusions as necessary.
8. Monitoring of the patient's urinary output and electrolyte levels.
9. Close monitoring of the patient's cardiovascular status, including frequent blood pressure measurements and cardiac output monitoring.
10. Consideration of invasive monitoring, including placement of a pulmonary artery catheter and arterial line, if necessary.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information is summarized:

The patient is an 85-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure and septic shock. She has a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.2°C (100.8°F)
* Heart rate: 79 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 94/51 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 19 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows:

* Central venous pressure: 6 mmHg
* Cardiac index: not specified
* Mean arterial pressure: not specified

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Lactic acid: 2.4 mmol/L
* TCO2: 18-20 mmol/L
* BNP: elevated
* CBC: not specified
* LFTs: obstructive with CBD dilation and sludge
* ABG: pH 7.31, PaO2 332, FiO2 40%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Intubated and sedated
* Clear lungs to auscultation
* Regular heart rhythm
* Soft and non-tender abdomen
* Warm and well-perfused extremities

The patient's potential medical complications are:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ABG results show good oxygenation, but her respiratory rate is still elevated. The patient's respiratory status may continue to deteriorate if not properly managed.
2. Sepsis: The patient's bandemia and lactate levels are improving, but she is still febrile and requiring pressors. The patient's sepsis may continue to worsen if not properly managed.
3. Anion gap acidosis: The patient's lactate levels are improving, but she still has a non-gap acidosis likely due to chronic diarrhea. The patient's acidosis may continue to worsen if not properly managed.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine levels are not specified, but her baseline creatinine is reported to be 1.2-1.4. The patient's kidney function may continue to deteriorate if not properly managed.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is not specified, but she is reported to have thrombocytopenia likely secondary to sepsis. The patient's thrombocytopenia may continue to worsen if not properly managed.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following plan is recommended:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin and pip-tazo.
2. Perform ERCP today for biliary drainage.
3. Trend CBC, lactate, and LFTs.
4. Follow up blood and urine cultures.
5. Continue IV fluids to maintain CVP 10-12 mmHg and good urine output.
6. Wean norepinephrine as tolerated by MAP >= 65 mmHg.
7. Check ScvO2.
8. Continue IV fluids per sepsis protocol.
9. Trend lactate and renal function.
10. Avoid nephrotoxins.
11. Send DIC labs.
12. Continue prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Summary:

The patient, an 85-year-old female, is critically ill in the ICU with a complex medical history, including choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia. She presents with acute respiratory failure, septic shock, anion gap acidosis, acute kidney injury, and thrombocytopenia. She has been treated with antibiotics, vasopressors, and fluids, and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and respiratory acidosis.
2. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing further sepsis-related complications, including organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Anion gap acidosis: The patient's anion gap acidosis may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further complications such as cardiac arrhythmias and kidney injury.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's AKI may progress to chronic kidney disease or require dialysis if not managed effectively.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may increase the risk of bleeding complications, including intracranial hemorrhage.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of hypertension and renal cancer may increase her risk of cardiac complications, including heart failure and arrhythmias.
7. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing further infections, including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and bloodstream infections.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of chronic diarrhea and vomiting may increase her risk of gastrointestinal complications, including bleeding and perforation.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and vasopressors, and consider further interventions such as ERCP for biliary drainage.
3. Monitor the patient's anion gap acidosis and adjust treatment as needed to prevent further complications.
4. Manage the patient's AKI with IV fluids and avoid nephrotoxins.
5. Monitor the patient's thrombocytopenia and consider transfusions if necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and consider further interventions such as echocardiography to evaluate for heart failure.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's infection risk and consider further interventions such as antibiotics and antifungals as needed.
8. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status closely and consider further interventions such as antacids and anti-diarrheal medications as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission, receiving mechanical ventilation and vasoactive infusions for hemodynamic support. They are receiving antibiotics, including vancomycin, and have a multi-lumen central line inserted. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.2°C, heart rate of 79 bpm, and blood pressure of 94/51 mmHg. Their respiratory status is also stable, with a SpO2 of 100% on 40% FiO2. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a central venous pressure of 6 mmHg, and their fluid balance is positive with a total input of 369 mL and output of 150 mL.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Infection: The patient's positive fluid balance and presence of a central line increase their risk of developing an infection. Close monitoring of their vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to detect any signs of infection early.
2. Venous thromboembolism (VTE): The patient's immobility and positive fluid balance increase their risk of developing VTE. Prophylactic measures such as compression stockings and early mobilization should be implemented.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable at present, but close monitoring is necessary to detect any signs of respiratory failure. Adjustments to their ventilator settings and oxygen therapy may be necessary to prevent respiratory failure.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is slightly low, and close monitoring is necessary to detect any signs of hypotension. Vasopressor support may be necessary to maintain adequate blood pressure.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's glycemic control is not mentioned in the note, and close monitoring of their blood glucose levels is necessary to prevent hyperglycemia.
6. Neurological compromise: The patient's neurological status is not assessed in the note, and close monitoring is necessary to detect any signs of neurological compromise.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's stress ulcer prophylaxis is not mentioned in the note, and close monitoring is necessary to detect any signs of gastrointestinal bleeding.

In conclusion, the patient is a high-risk ICU admission, and close monitoring is necessary to detect any signs of potential complications.

   85yo F with a h/o choledocholithiasis, HTN, renal CA, and dementia who
   presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory
   failure and septic shock likely secondary to biliary source. She is s/p
   ERCP and stent.
   .
   # Dyspnea/respiratory failure: Resp failure does not appear [**3-13**] primary
   lung process, as CXR is rather unimpressive, but suspect in setting of
   met acidosis she fatigued. Has been having recently worsening dyspnea
   on exertion, stable orthopnea. Became acutely SOB requiring intubation
   in the ED. Heart failure is less likely as echo and CXR do not show any
   evidence of this. ABG shows good oxygenation and patient has been
   switched to PSV 10/5 with FiO2 40%.
   - Cont PSV for now and wean as tolerated; consider sbt once patient can
   tolerate no sedation and no pressors
   - goal to extubate patient today
   # Septic shock:  Likely secondary to cholangitis and infected
   stone/sludge. ERCP yesterday showed significant pus and s/p stent
   placement. Patient afebrile and white count trending down. Lactate now
   normal. Initial sepsis likely secondary to biliary source given CBD
   dilation with sludge and obstructive LFTs in setting on known
   choledocholithiasis. No other source of infection found.
   - Cont broad spectrum abx with vancomycin and pip-tazo until
   sensitivies return
   - Trend CBC/diff, lactate, LFTs
   - Follow up blood cx , urine cx;  GPR may be contamination, but will
   continue to cover broadly for now until further speciation.
   - Cont IVF to keep CVP 10-12 mmHg and good UOP
   - Wean norepinephrine as tolerated by MAP >= 65 mmHg
   - Check ScvO2
   # ARF: Likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion
   secondary to vomiting and diarrhea. Currently stable at 2.1;  Baseline
   creatinine 1.2-1.4. - urine lytes: Fena: 0.2...pre-renal; in case she
   had lasix, FeUrea: 14.9%...pre-renal likely.
   - IVFs for CVP 10-12
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Trend renal function
   .
   #Thrombocytopenia Likely secondary to sepsis. DIC labs equivical; low
   suscipicion of HIT as timing does not correlate.
   - Concerning as platelets continuing to decrease. Vancomycin/Zosyn may
   be a possibility as known to cause thrombocytopenia.
   - Repeat DIC labs
   - No signs of active bleeding
   - Transfuse for less than 10,000 or 30,000 for procedure
   # Mixed Anion gap (lactic acid)/Non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea)
   acidosis:  Gap has closed. Lactate normalized.
    - Cont IVF per sepsis protocol; will give bicarb as needed for bicarb
   less than 18 or LR if needs resuscitation to prevent further  NG
   acidosis.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now in expectation of extubation today

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is an 85-year-old female who presents with dyspnea and vomiting, complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to a biliary source. She has a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia.

The patient underwent ERCP yesterday, which showed pus extruding from the major papilla and a choledochoduodenal fistula. A 10FR by 5cm double pigtail biliary stent was placed successfully. The patient was intubated in the emergency department due to acute respiratory failure.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.6°C (97.8°F)
* Heart rate: 71 bpm (normal range: 61-79 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 99/50 mmHg (normal range: 94-144/76-103 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 19 inspirations per minute (normal range: 8-23 inspirations per minute)
* SpO2: 98%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 25.0 x 10^9/L (normal range: 4.5-11.0 x 10^9/L)
* Hematocrit: 31.6% (normal range: 36-46%)
* Platelet count: 93 x 10^9/L (normal range: 150-450 x 10^9/L)
* Creatinine: 2.1 mg/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.2 mg/dL)
* Lactic acid: 1.4 mmol/L (normal range: 0.5-2.0 mmol/L)
* D-dimer: 9424 ng/mL (normal range: 0-500 ng/mL)

The patient's medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation.
* Septic shock: The patient has sepsis likely secondary to cholangitis and infected stone/sludge.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and the patient is receiving IV fluids to maintain a CVP of 10-12 mmHg.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and the patient is at risk for bleeding.
* Mixed anion gap/non-anion gap acidosis: The patient's acidosis is likely secondary to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam until sensitivities return.
* Trending CBC, lactate, and LFTs.
* Following up blood and urine cultures.
* Continuing IV fluids to maintain a CVP of 10-12 mmHg and good urine output.
* Weaning norepinephrine as tolerated by MAP >= 65 mmHg.
* Checking ScvO2.
* Avoiding nephrotoxins and transfusing for less than 10,000 or 30,000 for procedure.
* Repeating DIC labs.

The patient is currently receiving ICU care, including mechanical ventilation, IV fluids, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. The patient's disposition is ICU for now.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia who presented with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to biliary source. She underwent ERCP and stent placement yesterday.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: intubated, on PSV 10/5 with FiO2 40%, and showing good oxygenation (SpO2 98%)
* Hemodynamic status: MAP 62-103, HR 60-80, and RR 19
* Cardiac status: atrial fibrillation (AFib) with rates 100-115, which is being managed with ACV
* Renal status: acute kidney injury (ARF) likely secondary to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion
* Thrombocytopenia: platelet count decreasing, likely secondary to sepsis
* Infection: sepsis from cholangitis, treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics (Zosyn) and awaiting sensitivities
* Laboratory results:
	+ WBC: 17.8 K/uL
	+ Hct: 31.6%
	+ Plt: 48
	+ Na: 137 mmol/L
	+ Cr: 2.1 mg/dL
	+ Lactate: 1.4 mmol/L
	+ TropT: 0.02 ng/mL
	+ TCO2: 18 mmol/L
	+ Glucose: 195 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: AFib can lead to hemodynamic instability, and the patient's underlying sepsis and renal failure may also contribute to cardiac issues.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, and she may develop respiratory acidosis.
3. Renal complications: The patient's ARF may progress, and she may require dialysis.
4. Infection complications: The patient's sepsis may worsen, and she may develop septic shock.
5. Bleeding complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia may increase the risk of bleeding, especially if she requires invasive procedures or surgery.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's ARF and electrolyte imbalance may lead to electrolyte disturbances, such as hyperkalemia or hypokalemia.

The plan of care includes:

1. Continue IVF boluses for CVP and U/O
2. Wean pressor, maintaining MAPS > 65
3. Monitor resp and hemodynamic status closely and consider repeat SBT later in the afternoon
4. Continue treatment for biliary sepsis with antibiotics
5. Monitor infection parameters and adjust treatment as necessary
6. Hold heparin products and monitor for signs of HIT or DIC
7. Continue ICU prophylaxis and monitor for signs of bleeding or infection.

   placement. Patient afebrile and white count trending down. Lactate now
   normal. Initial sepsis likely secondary to biliary source given CBD
   dilation with sludge and obstructive LFTs in setting on known
   choledocholithiasis. No other source of infection found.
   - Cont broad spectrum abx with pip-tazo until sensitivies return; d/c
   vanc as GI infection not likely MRSA.
   - Trend CBC/diff, LFTs
   - Follow up blood cx , urine cx;  GPR may be contamination, but will
   continue to cover broadly for now until further speciation.
   - Cont IVF to keep CVP 10-12 mmHg and good UOP
   - Wean norepinephrine as tolerated by MAP >= 65 mmHg
   # ARF: Likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion
   secondary to vomiting and diarrhea. Currently stable at 2.1;  Baseline
   creatinine 1.2-1.4. - urine lytes: Fena: 0.2...pre-renal; in case she
   had lasix, FeUrea: 14.9%...pre-renal likely. Since fluids do not seem
   to correct very fast, likely a component of ATN as well.
   - IVFs for CVP 10-12
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Trend renal function with PM chem. 10.

   less than 18 or LR if needs resuscitation to prevent further  NG

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia who presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to biliary source. She underwent ERCP and stent placement yesterday. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. She has atrial fibrillation, which is being managed with levophed and is being weaned off sedation. Her septic shock is likely secondary to cholangitis and infected stone/sludge. She has acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and mixed anion gap/non-anion gap acidosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may persist or worsen, leading to hemodynamic instability and potentially life-threatening arrhythmias.
2. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock may progress or worsen, leading to multi-organ failure and increased risk of mortality.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may not respond to treatment, leading to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to bleeding complications or increased risk of bleeding.
5. Mixed Anion Gap/Non-Anion Gap Acidosis: The patient's acidosis may not respond to treatment, leading to further acidosis and potential organ damage.
6. Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC): Although the patient's DIC panel is equivocal, there is a low suspicion of DIC, and further monitoring is necessary to rule out this condition.
7. Hepatorenal Syndrome: The patient's liver dysfunction may lead to hepatorenal syndrome, which can worsen her renal function and increase her risk of mortality.
8. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to prolonged mechanical ventilation and increased risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia.
9. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's cardiovascular system may be compromised due to her septic shock, leading to decreased cardiac output and increased risk of cardiovascular complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory values closely to identify any potential complications.
2. Adjust the patient's treatment plan as necessary to address any emerging complications.
3. Consider consulting with a nephrologist or cardiologist to optimize the patient's care.
4. Monitor the patient's fluid status and electrolyte levels to prevent further acidosis.
5. Consider transferring the patient to a higher level of care if her condition worsens or if she requires more intensive treatment.
6. Educate the patient's family and caregivers on her condition and treatment plan to ensure they are aware of her needs and can provide support.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia who presented with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to a biliary source. She underwent ERCP and stent placement.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: Intubated and on CPAP/PSV with FiO2 40% due to acute respiratory failure.
* Cardiac status: Mildly dilated left atrium, normal left ventricular function, and high-normal pulmonary artery systolic pressure.
* Hemodynamic status: Hemodynamically stable with a central venous pressure (CVP) of 7-8 mmHg and mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 99/50 mmHg.
* Renal status: Acute kidney injury (AKI) with a baseline creatinine of 1.2-1.4 mg/dL and current creatinine of 2.1 mg/dL.
* Coagulation status: Thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 48,000/μL, and a low suspicion of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).
* Infectious status: Septic shock likely secondary to cholangitis and infected stone/sludge, with a trend towards resolving fever and white blood cell count.

The patient's medications include:

* Midazolam (Versed) 2 mg/hour
* Fentanyl 50 mcg/hour
* Norepinephrine 0.08 mcg/kg/min
* Heparin sodium (prophylaxis)
* Vancomycin (discontinued)
* Piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn)

The patient's plan includes:

* Weaning of pressors as tolerated
* Attempt to change back to pressure support ventilation (PSV) and wean as tolerated
* Goal to extubate the patient today
* Contingency plan for atrial fibrillation (AFib) and septic shock
* Monitoring of renal function and acid-base status
* Transfusion of platelets if necessary
* Discontinuation of vancomycin and heparin due to thrombocytopenia and low suspicion of HIT

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued septic shock and organ dysfunction
* Prolonged intubation and respiratory failure
* Acute kidney injury and need for renal replacement therapy
* Thrombocytopenia and bleeding complications
* Atrial fibrillation and potential need for cardioversion
* Infection and sepsis due to the presence of a choledochoduodenal fistula and infected stone/sludge.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 85-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, septic shock, and atrial fibrillation. She underwent ERCP yesterday, which showed a choledochoduodenal fistula, a 2.5-3cm filling defect consistent with a stone or sludge ball, and partial obstruction at the mid CBD. A 10FR by 5cm double pigtail biliary stent was placed successfully.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: Intubated and on CPAP/PSV with FiO2 40%. She is currently stable, but has had episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate (RVR).
* Hemodynamic status: CVP 7-8 mmHg, MAP 99-50 mmHg, and Norepinephrine infusion at 0.08 mcg/kg/min. She is currently stable, but has had episodes of hemodynamic instability.
* Renal status: Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL, and urine output has been improving with IVF and bicarbonate administration.
* Coagulation status: Platelet count is decreasing, and she has a suspicion of HIT. DIC panel is pending.
* Infection status: She has a choledochoduodenal fistula, and her white blood cell count is trending down. She is on broad-spectrum antibiotics, and her lactate level is normal.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation, but there is a risk of further respiratory deterioration, particularly if she develops pneumonia or other respiratory complications.
* Cardiac complications: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which may lead to further cardiac complications, such as heart failure or cardiac arrest.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and she may be at risk of further renal deterioration, particularly if she develops septic shock or other complications.
* Coagulopathy: The patient's platelet count is decreasing, and she may be at risk of further bleeding or clotting complications.
* Infection: The patient has a choledochoduodenal fistula, and there is a risk of further infection or sepsis, particularly if the stent becomes dislodged or the patient develops other complications.

Based on this information, the patient's plan of care should include:

* Continuing respiratory support with CPAP/PSV and FiO2 40%.
* Weaning of Norepinephrine infusion as tolerated.
* Monitoring of renal function and urine output.
* Monitoring of coagulation status and platelet count.
* Continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics for choledochoduodenal fistula and potential sepsis.
* Monitoring for signs of cardiac complications, such as heart failure or cardiac arrest.
* Monitoring for signs of respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or respiratory failure.
* Considering extubation today if the patient's respiratory status improves.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure, which may progress to chronic respiratory failure if not managed properly.
2. Septic shock: The patient has septic shock likely secondary to cholangitis and infected stone/sludge, which may lead to multi-organ failure if not treated promptly and effectively.
3. Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient has ARF likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion, which may progress to chronic kidney disease if not managed properly.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia likely secondary to sepsis, which may increase the risk of bleeding if not managed properly.
5. Mixed anion gap (lactic acid)/Non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea) acidosis: The patient has acidosis, which may worsen if not managed properly.
6. Cholangitis: The patient has cholangitis, which may lead to further complications such as liver abscesses or sepsis if not treated promptly and effectively.
7. Infected stone/sludge: The patient has infected stone/sludge, which may lead to further complications such as sepsis or abscesses if not treated promptly and effectively.

To mitigate these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored and managed in the ICU. This includes:

* Continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover potential infections
* Trending CBC/diff, lactate, LFTs, and renal function to monitor for signs of sepsis, ARF, and cholangitis
* Weaning sedation and pressors as tolerated
* Maintaining CVP 10-12 mmHg and good UOP
* Avoiding nephrotoxins and transfusing platelets if necessary
* Monitoring for signs of bleeding and platelet transfusion if necessary
* Managing acidosis with IVF and bicarbonate as needed
* Considering extubation and transfer to a medical ward once the patient is stable and able to tolerate no sedation and no pressors.

   ERCP: The major papilla was intra-diverticular. Pus was seen extruding
   from the major papilla. An opening draining bile and pus consistent
   with a choledochoduodenal fistula was seen at the superior portion of
   the major papilla. Cannulation of the biliary duct was successful and
   deep with a sphincterotome using a free-hand technique. Contrast medium
   was injected resulting in complete opacification.  A single 2.5-3cm
   filling defect consistent witha stone or sludge ball that was causing
   partial obstruction was seen at the mid CBD.  A 10FR by 5cm double
   pigtail biliary stent was placed successfully using a Oasis 10FR stent
   introducer kit.
   Echo: The left atrium is mildly dilated. Left ventricular wall
   thickness, cavity size and regional/global systolic function are normal
   (LVEF >65%). The estimated cardiac index is normal (>=2.5L/min/m2).
   Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The
   aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is
   not present. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve
   leaflets are structurally normal. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is
   seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is high normal.
   There is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion.
   Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of [**2165-12-23**], the left
   ventricle is less dynamic, the velocity across the aortic valve is
   lower (now normal), and the severity of tricuspid regurgitation and
   pulmonary artery systolic pressure are lower.
   Assessment and Plan
   85yo F with a h/o choledocholithiasis, HTN, renal CA, and dementia who
   presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory
   failure and septic shock likely secondary to biliary source. She is s/p
   ERCP and stent.
   .
   # Dyspnea/respiratory failure: Resp failure does not appear [**3-13**] primary
   lung process, as CXR is rather unimpressive, but suspect in setting of
   met acidosis she fatigued. Has been having recently worsening dyspnea
   on exertion, stable orthopnea. Became acutely SOB requiring intubation
   in the ED. Heart failure is less likely as echo and CXR do not show any
   evidence of this. ABG shows good oxygenation and patient has been
   switched to PSV 10/5 with FiO2 40%.  Some hemodynamic instability
   during SBT, with afib on AC for now.
   - Attempt to change back to PSV for now and wean as tolerated; consider
   sbt once patient can tolerate no sedation
   - wean pressors as tolerated
   - goal to extubate patient today
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Appears to be first episode as no history of
   this in past. Likely exacerbated by SBT and being on levophed in the
   setting of infection. Hemodynamically stable for now with rates in the
   110
   - EKG
   -  If fast rate persists or if worsening hemodynamics, consider
   changing levophed to phenylephrine as to reduce beta agonist activity
   and worsen afib with RVR.
   # Septic shock:  Likely secondary to cholangitis and infected
   stone/sludge. ERCP yesterday showed significant pus and s/p stent
   placement. Patient afebrile and white count trending down. Lactate now
   normal. Initial sepsis likely secondary to biliary source given CBD
   dilation with sludge and obstructive LFTs in setting on known
   choledocholithiasis. No other source of infection found.
   - Cont broad spectrum abx with pip-tazo until sensitivies return; d/c
   vanc as GI infection not likely MRSA.
   - Trend CBC/diff, LFTs
   - Follow up blood cx , urine cx;  GPR may be contamination, but will
   continue to cover broadly for now until further speciation.
   - Cont IVF to keep CVP 10-12 mmHg and good UOP
   - Wean norepinephrine as tolerated by MAP >= 65 mmHg
   # ARF: Likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion
   secondary to vomiting and diarrhea. Currently stable at 2.1;  Baseline
   creatinine 1.2-1.4. - urine lytes: Fena: 0.2...pre-renal; in case she
   had lasix, FeUrea: 14.9%...pre-renal likely. Since fluids do not seem
   to correct very fast, likely a component of ATN as well.
   - IVFs for CVP 10-12
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Trend renal function with PM chem. 10.
   .
   #Thrombocytopenia Likely secondary to sepsis. DIC and repeat labs
   equivical; low suscipicion of HIT as timing does not correlate.
   Concerning as platelets continuing to decrease. Vancomycin/ may be a
   possibility as known to cause thrombocytopenia.
   - D/C vanc and heparin today
   - unlikely DIC at this point
   - No signs of active bleeding
   - Re-check cbc at 1500
   - Transfuse for less than 10,000 or 30,000 for procedure
   # Mixed Anion gap (lactic acid)/Non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea)
   acidosis:  Gap has closed. Lactate normalized.
    - Cont IVF per sepsis protocol; will give bicarb as needed for bicarb
   less than 18 or LR if needs resuscitation to prevent further  NG
   acidosis.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO pending hopeful extubation this morning

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia who presented with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to biliary source. She underwent ERCP and stent placement. The patient has been intubated and is currently on mechanical ventilation. She has been experiencing atrial fibrillation, which is likely exacerbated by the septic shock and infection. The patient's hemodynamics are stable, and she is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and vasopressors.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely to persist, and there is a risk of worsening hemodynamics if the rate becomes too fast.
2. Septic shock: The patient's septic shock is likely to continue, and there is a risk of further organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's ARF is likely to persist, and there is a risk of further kidney damage and failure.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely to continue, and there is a risk of bleeding complications.
5. Mixed anion gap (lactic acid)/non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea) acidosis: The patient's acidosis is likely to persist, and there is a risk of further acidosis and organ dysfunction.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to continue, and there is a risk of further respiratory compromise and failure.
7. Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac failure is likely to persist, and there is a risk of further cardiac compromise and failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics and vasopressors to manage septic shock and atrial fibrillation.
2. Monitor the patient's hemodynamics and adjust therapy as needed to prevent worsening of atrial fibrillation and septic shock.
3. Continue to treat the patient's ARF with IV fluids and avoid nephrotoxins.
4. Monitor the patient's thrombocytopenia and platelet count, and consider transfusion if necessary.
5. Continue to manage the patient's acidosis with IV fluids and bicarbonate as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as needed to prevent further respiratory compromise and failure.
7. Consider transferring the patient to a cardiac intensive care unit (ICU) for further management of her cardiac status.

   the major papilla. Cannulation of the biliary duct was successful and
   deep with a sphincterotome using a free-hand technique. Contrast medium
   was injected resulting in complete opacification.  A single 2.5-3cm
   filling defect consistent witha stone or sludge ball that was causing
   partial obstruction was seen at the mid CBD.  A 10FR by 5cm double
   pigtail biliary stent was placed successfully using a Oasis 10FR stent
   introducer kit.
   Echo: The left atrium is mildly dilated. Left ventricular wall
   thickness, cavity size and regional/global systolic function are normal
   (LVEF >65%). The estimated cardiac index is normal (>=2.5L/min/m2).
   Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The
   aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is
   not present. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve
   leaflets are structurally normal. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is
   seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is high normal.
   There is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion.
   Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of [**2165-12-23**], the left
   ventricle is less dynamic, the velocity across the aortic valve is
   lower (now normal), and the severity of tricuspid regurgitation and
   pulmonary artery systolic pressure are lower.

   85yo F with a h/o choledocholithiasis, HTN, renal CA, and dementia who
   presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory
   failure and septic shock likely secondary to biliary source. She is s/p
   ERCP and stent.
   .

   lung process, as CXR is rather unimpressive, but in the setting of her
   metabolic acidosis she was hyperventilating to compensate and
   fatigued. Becoming acutely SOB and requiring intubation in the ED. Has
   been doing well on the ventilator, had hoped to extubate her yesterday,
   however she went into A.fib with RVR during her [**Last Name (LF) 1324**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] she was
   intially changed back to A/C, then transitioned back to PSV.
   - [**First Name3 (LF) 1324**] early this morning, discontinue sedation for hopeful extubation
   this morning
   # Atrial Fibrillation: First occurred during [**First Name3 (LF) 1324**] on [**11-23**], initially
   rates were in the 110
s, then increased to the 130
s, pressor changed
   from levophed to neo without any effect, her BP dropped with IV dilt,
   so started amiodarone morning of [**11-24**] due to continued pressor
   requirement
   - Monitor for improvement and hopeful d/c of amio once patient is
   extubated and off sedation
   # Septic shock:  Likely secondary to cholangitis and infected
   stone/sludge. ERCP showed significant pusand very large stone, she is
   s/p stent placement. Patient afebrile and white count trending down.
   Lactate now normal. Initial sepsis likely secondary to biliary source
   given CBD dilation with sludge and obstructive LFTs in setting on known
   choledocholithiasis. No other source of infection found.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following are the key points and potential medical complications:

**Key Points:**

* The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia who presented with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to a biliary source.
* She underwent ERCP with stent placement and has been intubated and on mechanical ventilation.
* She developed atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate, which was treated with amiodarone.
* She has septic shock likely secondary to cholangitis and infected stone/sludge, and her lactate has normalized.
* She has acute respiratory failure, which is not primarily related to a lung process.
* She has acute kidney injury likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion.
* She has thrombocytopenia likely secondary to sepsis, and her platelet count is slightly increasing.
* She has mixed anion gap (lactic acid)/non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea) acidosis, which has resolved.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is not primarily related to a lung process, but she may still be at risk for further respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or ventilator-associated lung injury.
* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely secondary to a biliary source, and she may still be at risk for further septic complications, such as organ failure or death.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion, and she may still be at risk for further kidney injury or failure.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely secondary to sepsis, and she may still be at risk for bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial bleeding.
* Mixed anion gap (lactic acid)/non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea) acidosis: The patient's acidosis has resolved, but she may still be at risk for further acidosis or other electrolyte imbalances.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely related to her underlying medical conditions and may still be at risk for further complications, such as stroke or heart failure.
* Cholangitis: The patient's cholangitis is likely secondary to a biliary source, and she may still be at risk for further complications, such as biliary obstruction or pancreatitis.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

**Summary:**

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia who presented with dyspnea and vomiting, complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to a biliary source. She underwent ERCP and stent placement, and has been admitted to the ICU for further management.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Atrial Fibrillation (AFib):** The patient developed AFib during her ICU stay, which was treated with amiodarone. She will need to be monitored for improvement and potential discontinuation of amiodarone once she is extubated and off sedation.
2. **Septic Shock:** The patient's septic shock is likely secondary to cholangitis and infected stone/sludge. She is at risk for further infection, and will need to be recultured and monitored for signs of sepsis.
3. **Acute Respiratory Failure (ARF):** The patient's ARF is likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion. She will need to be weaned off pressors and monitored for signs of improvement.
4. **Thrombocytopenia:** The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely secondary to sepsis. She will need to be monitored for signs of active bleeding and transfused if necessary.
5. **Acidosis:** The patient's mixed anion gap (lactic acid)/non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea) acidosis has resolved, but she will need to be monitored for signs of acidosis.
6. **Kidney Injury:** The patient's kidney injury is likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion. She will need to be monitored for signs of kidney recovery.
7. **Infection:** The patient is at risk for further infection, and will need to be recultured and monitored for signs of sepsis.

**Other Notes:**

* The patient's husband is her healthcare proxy.
* The patient's daughter is a healthcare provider.
* The patient's disposition is ICU.

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old female who presented with dyspnea and vomiting, complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to biliary source. She underwent ERCP and stent placement, and was intubated in the ED. She has been on the ventilator and has required pressors to maintain blood pressure. She has developed atrial fibrillation, which was treated with amiodarone, and has also had thrombocytopenia, which is likely secondary to sepsis. Her renal function has been impaired, and she has developed an anion gap acidosis, which has since resolved.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to continue, and she may require prolonged mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to persist, and she may require continued antimicrobial therapy.
3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may require continued treatment with amiodarone, and she may be at risk for stroke or embolism.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may persist, and she may be at risk for bleeding.
5. Renal Failure: The patient's renal failure may persist, and she may require continued dialysis.
6. Anion Gap Acidosis: The patient's anion gap acidosis has resolved, but she may be at risk for recurrent episodes.
7. Choledocholithiasis: The patient's choledocholithiasis may require continued treatment, and she may be at risk for recurrent episodes.
8. Bile Duct Obstruction: The patient's bile duct obstruction may require continued treatment, and she may be at risk for recurrent episodes.

ICU Care:

1. Nutrition: The patient will be placed on a tube feeding regimen to provide adequate nutrition.
2. Glycemic Control: The patient's blood glucose levels will be monitored and treated as necessary to prevent hyperglycemia.
3. Lines: The patient will have multiple lines inserted, including an arterial line and a central venous catheter.
4. Prophylaxis: The patient will receive prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.
5. Communication: The patient's family will be kept informed of her condition and any changes that occur.
6. Disposition: The patient will remain in the ICU for further treatment and monitoring.

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia who presented with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to biliary source. She underwent ERCP and stent placement. She remains intubated and has developed atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which was treated with amiodarone. Her renal function has not improved as quickly as expected, and she has developed thrombocytopenia likely secondary to sepsis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to persist due to her chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and her recent respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to continue due to her biliary source of infection and her recent antibiotic treatment.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely to persist due to her underlying cardiac disease and her recent treatment with amiodarone.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely to persist due to her sepsis and her recent treatment with antibiotics.
5. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is likely to persist due to her underlying chronic kidney disease and her recent treatment with diuretics.
6. Biliary sepsis: The patient's biliary sepsis is likely to persist due to her underlying biliary disease and her recent treatment with antibiotics.
7. Infection: The patient's infection is likely to persist due to her recent antibiotic treatment and her underlying chronic disease.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her respiratory therapy as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's sepsis and adjust her antibiotic treatment as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation and adjust her treatment as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's thrombocytopenia and adjust her treatment as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust her treatment as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's biliary sepsis and adjust her treatment as needed.
7. Consider repeating the patient's blood cultures to rule out new infections.
8. Consider repeating the patient's urine cultures to rule out new infections.
9. Consider repeating the patient's stool cultures to rule out new infections.
10. Consider repeating the patient's liver function tests to rule out new liver dysfunction.

   85yo F with a h/o choledocholithiasis, HTN, renal CA, and dementia who
   presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory
   failure and septic shock likely secondary to cholangitis. She is s/p
   ERCP and stent.
   .
   # Dyspnea/respiratory failure: Resp failure does not appear [**3-13**] primary
   lung process, as CXR is rather unimpressive, but in the setting of her
   metabolic acidosis she was hyperventilating to compensate and
   fatigued. Becoming acutely SOB and requiring intubation in the ED.
   Unable to wean effectively; likely secondary to fluid resuscitation; as
   fluid overload is seen on CXR.
   - Monitor UOP as patient is auto-diuresing well. Check i/o
s this
   evening with TBB 1-1.5 liters
   - Wean down vent settings as much as possible, will likely be more
   effective once
   - CXR today to make sure no other acute process is occuring
   # Atrial Fibrillation: First occurred during SBT on [**11-23**], initially
   rates were in the 110
s, then increased to the 130
s, pressor changed
   from levophed to neo without any effect, her BP dropped with IV dilt,
   so started amiodarone morning of [**11-24**] due to continued pressor
   requirement
   - Continue amio gtt as HR has improved, but she is still tachycardic in
   the low 100
   - Monitor for improvement and hopeful d/c of amio once patient is
   extubated and off sedation
   # Septic shock:  Likely secondary to cholangitis and infected
   stone/sludge. ERCP showed significant pusand very large stone, she is
   s/p stent placement. Patient afebrile and white count trending down.
   Lactate now normal. Initial sepsis likely secondary to biliary source
   given CBD dilation with sludge and obstructive LFTs in setting on known
   choledocholithiasis. No other source of infection found.
   - Leukocytosis is resolveing, T max was yesterday at 1600; appears to
   be improving.
   - Cont zosyn pending any further culture data; Day [**5-19**] of zosyn. Day
   1: [**11-22**].
   - f/u speciation and sensitivities from prior blood cx
   - Trend CBC/diff, LFTs,
   - Follow up blood cx speciation , urine cx with no growth
   - no need for pressors now. Monitor maps > 65.
   .
   # ARF: Improved, near baseline. Likely related to sepsis and
   intravascular volume depletion secondary to vomiting and diarrhea, also
   likely some component of ATN as her renal function has not improved as
   quickly with fluids as would be expected in a purely pre-renal picture.
   Cr improving to 1.5 today, baseline creatinine 1.2-1.4.
   - Monitor UOP
   - Trend creatinine
   .

   thrombocytopenia
   - Continue to hold vanc/heparin

   - Transfuse for less than 10,000 or 30,000 for procedure
   - If platelets remain stable or increase tomorrow would restart heparin
   as HIT is very unlikely

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia who presented with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to cholangitis. She underwent ERCP and stent placement. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure and septic shock.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38°C, heart rate of 141 bpm, and blood pressure of 109/60 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 25 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 99%. Her cardiac rhythm is atrial fibrillation, and her peripheral oxygen saturation is 99%.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 17.8 K/μL, with a trend of decreasing white blood cell count. Her hemoglobin is 9.8 g/dL, and her platelet count is 48 K/μL. Her creatinine is 1.5 mg/dL, and her lactate is 1.7 mmol/L.

The patient's medical history includes a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia. She has also had a recent ERCP and stent placement.

The patient's current medications include amiodarone, midazolam, and fentanyl.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to septic shock and cholangitis. The patient's respiratory rate is 25 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 99%. The patient's CXR is unimpressive, but her metabolic acidosis may be contributing to her hyperventilation.
2. Septic Shock: The patient's septic shock is likely secondary to cholangitis and infected stone/sludge. The patient's lactate is 1.7 mmol/L, and her white blood cell count is 17.8 K/μL. The patient's temperature is 38°C, and her heart rate is 141 bpm.
3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely secondary to septic shock and cholangitis. The patient's heart rate is 141 bpm, and her cardiac rhythm is atrial fibrillation.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely secondary to sepsis. The patient's platelet count is 48 K/μL, and her bleeding time is normal.
5. Mixed Anion Gap (Lactic Acid)/Non-anion Gap (NS and Diarrhea) Acidosis: The patient's acidosis is likely secondary to septic shock and cholangitis. The patient's lactate is 1.7 mmol/L, and her bicarbonate is 24 mmol/L.
6. ARF: The patient's acute renal failure is likely secondary to septic shock and cholangitis. The patient's creatinine is 1.5 mg/dL, and her urine output is 50-180 cc/hour.

Recommendations:

1. Monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
2. Continue to manage the patient's septic shock with fluid resuscitation and pressor support as needed.
3. Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with amiodarone and monitor for improvement.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's thrombocytopenia and bleeding time.
5. Continue to manage the patient's mixed anion gap (lactic acid)/non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea) acidosis with bicarbonate administration.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's acute renal failure and urine output.
7. Consider extubating the patient once her respiratory failure has improved and her acidosis has resolved.
8. Consider restarting heparin once the patient's platelet count has increased and her bleeding time has normalized.

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Patient's Condition:**

* The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia.
* She presents with dyspnea and vomiting, complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to biliary source.
* She has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation.
* Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38°C, heart rate of 141 bpm, and blood pressure of 109/60 mmHg.
* Her respiratory support is set to CPAP/PSV with a Vt of 500 mL and a PEEP of 5 cmH2O.
* She has a mixed anion gap (lactic acid)/non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea) acidosis, which has resolved with bicarbonate therapy.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Atrial Fibrillation:** The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely secondary to sepsis and may require continued monitoring and potential discontinuation of amiodarone once she is extubated and off sedation.
2. **Septic Shock:** The patient's septic shock is likely secondary to cholangitis and infected stone/sludge. Her white blood cell count is trending down, and lactate is normal, but she is at risk for a new infection, and reculture blood, urine, and sputum will be performed.
3. **Acute Respiratory Failure:** The patient's acute respiratory failure is likely secondary to sepsis and may require continued mechanical ventilation. Weaning off the ventilator will depend on her ability to diurese and her respiratory function.
4. **Acute Kidney Injury (ARF):** The patient's ARF is likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion secondary to vomiting and diarrhea. Her renal function has not improved as quickly with fluids as would be expected in a purely pre-renal picture.
5. **Thrombocytopenia:** The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely secondary to sepsis and may require continued monitoring and potential transfusion.
6. **Mixed Anion Gap (lactic acid)/Non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea) Acidosis:** The patient's acidosis has resolved with bicarbonate therapy, but she is at risk for reoccurrence.

**Plan:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and respiratory function.
* Wean off the ventilator once the patient is able to diurese and her respiratory function improves.
* Continue to monitor for signs of infection and reculture blood, urine, and sputum as needed.
* Titrate MAP to greater than 60 mmHg unless urine output decreases.
* Continue to hold vancomycin and heparin until further evaluation of the patient's platelet count and coagulation status.
* Transfuse platelets if the patient's platelet count remains low or decreases further.
* Monitor for signs of bleeding and adjust anticoagulation therapy as needed.
* Continue to provide OG tube feeds and monitor for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding or other complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   85yo F with a h/o choledocholithiasis, HTN, renal CA, and dementia who
   presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory
   failure and septic shock likely secondary to cholangitis. She is s/p
   ERCP and stent.
   .
   # Dyspnea/respiratory failure: Resp failure does not appear [**3-13**] primary
   lung process, as CXR is rather unimpressive, but in the setting of her
   metabolic acidosis she was hyperventilating to compensate and
   fatigued. Becoming acutely SOB and requiring intubation in the ED.
   Unable to wean effectively; likely secondary to fluid resuscitation; as
   fluid overload is seen on CXR.
   - Monitor UOP as patient is auto-diuresing well. Check i/o
s this
   evening with TBB 1-1.5 liters
   - Wean down vent settings as much as possible, will likely be more
   effective once
   - CXR today to make sure no other acute process is occuring
   # Atrial Fibrillation: First occurred during SBT on [**11-23**], initially
   rates were in the 110
s, then increased to the 130
s, pressor changed
   from levophed to neo without any effect, her BP dropped with IV dilt,
   so started amiodarone morning of [**11-24**] due to continued pressor
   requirement
   - Continue amio gtt as HR has improved, but she is still tachycardic in
   the low 100
   - Monitor for improvement and hopeful d/c of amio once patient is
   extubated and off sedation
   # Septic shock:  Likely secondary to cholangitis and infected
   stone/sludge. ERCP showed significant pusand very large stone, she is
   s/p stent placement. Patient afebrile and white count trending down.
   Lactate now normal. Initial sepsis likely secondary to biliary source
   given CBD dilation with sludge and obstructive LFTs in setting on known
   choledocholithiasis. No other source of infection found.
   - Leukocytosis is resolveing, T max was yesterday at 1600; appears to
   be improving.
   - Cont zosyn pending any further culture data; Day [**5-19**] of zosyn. Day
   1: [**11-22**].
   - f/u speciation and sensitivities from prior blood cx
   - Trend CBC/diff, LFTs,
   - Follow up blood cx speciation , urine cx with no growth
   - no need for pressors now. Monitor maps > 65.
   .
   # ARF: Improved, near baseline. Likely related to sepsis and
   intravascular volume depletion secondary to vomiting and diarrhea, also
   likely some component of ATN as her renal function has not improved as
   quickly with fluids as would be expected in a purely pre-renal picture.
   Cr improving to 1.5 today, baseline creatinine 1.2-1.4.
   - Monitor UOP
   - Trend creatinine
   .
   #Thrombocytopenia Stable. Likely secondary to sepsis. Low suscipicion
   of HIT as timing does not correlate since patient has not had a prior
   heparin exposure.  Vancomycin may also be contributing to her
   thrombocytopenia
   - Continue to hold vanc/heparin
   - No signs of active bleeding
   - Transfuse for less than 10,000 or 30,000 for procedure
   - If platelets remain stable or increase tomorrow would restart heparin
   as HIT is very unlikely
   # Mixed Anion gap (lactic acid)/Non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea)
   acidosis:  Gap has closed. Lactate normalized.
    - Bicarb 24 today, extubation will be facilitated by resolution of
   acidosis.

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia who was admitted with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to cholangitis. She underwent ERCP and stent placement. The patient is currently intubated and on ventilator support.

Current Vital Signs:

* Temperature: 38°C (100.4°F)
* Heart rate: 141 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 109/60 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 25 inspirations per minute (IPM)
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* Atrial fibrillation

Lab Results:

* White blood cell count: 17.8 K/μL (increasing)
* Hematocrit: 30.8%
* Platelet count: 48 K/μL (stable)
* Creatinine: 1.5 mg/dL (improving)
* Blood urea nitrogen: 23 mg/dL (normal)
* Lactic acid: 1.7 mmol/L (normal)
* Glucose: 151 mg/dL (normal)

Medical Complications:

* Septic shock likely secondary to cholangitis and infected stone/sludge
* Acute respiratory failure
* Mixed anion gap (lactic acid)/non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea) acidosis
* Thrombocytopenia likely secondary to sepsis
* Atrial fibrillation

Potential Medical Complications:

* Failure to wean from ventilator support
* Development of respiratory failure
* Continued sepsis and septic shock
* Thrombotic complications (e.g., deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism)
* Renal failure
* Hepatic failure
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Infection-related complications (e.g., pneumonia, urinary tract infection)

Plan:

* Continue to monitor vital signs and lab results
* Wean from ventilator support as tolerated
* Continue antibiotics and antifungal therapy as necessary
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and septic shock
* Consider PICC line placement if sensitivities of cultures do not return
* Consider full 10-day course of zosyn if necessary
* Monitor for signs of thrombotic complications and take appropriate measures to prevent them
* Continue to monitor renal function and adjust fluid management as necessary
* Monitor for signs of hepatic failure and take appropriate measures to prevent it
* Monitor for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding and take appropriate measures to prevent it
* Consider extubation once patient is stable and off sedation.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 38°C (100.4°F)
* Heart rate: 128 bpm (114-141 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 111/67 mmHg (76-127/54-81 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 23 breaths per minute (14-30 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* Heart rhythm: Atrial fibrillation

The patient has several medical complications, including:

* Respiratory failure, likely secondary to volume overload
* Septic shock, which has resolved off pressors and autodiuresis
* Thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 48 K/uL
* Atrial fibrillation, which is being treated with amiodarone
* Lactic acidosis, with a level of 1.7 mmol/L
* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level, at 203 IU/L

The patient is receiving several medications, including:

* Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn) for septic shock
* Amiodarone for atrial fibrillation
* Fentanyl for pain management
* Midazolam (Versed) for sedation
* Other medications, including lasix, heparin, and antibiotics

The patient's laboratory results show:

The patient's radiology results show:

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing antibiotics for septic shock

* Continuing amiodarone for atrial fibrillation
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis or organ dysfunction

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Further deterioration of respiratory function

* Sepsis or organ dysfunction due to new infections or worsening of existing infections

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications are noted:

**Summary:**

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, dementia, and renal cancer, who presents with septic shock, cholangitis, and respiratory failure. She has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. She has been treated with piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn) and is off pressors. Her laboratory results show leukocytosis, and her liver function tests (LFTs) are improving after stenting via ERCP. She has atrial fibrillation and thrombocytopenia.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Volume Overload:** The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to volume overload, which may worsen her condition and increase the risk of cardiac complications.
2. **Infection:** The patient's septic shock and cholangitis indicate a high risk of infection, which may lead to further complications, such as organ failure and sepsis.
3. **Atrial Fibrillation:** The patient's atrial fibrillation may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as stroke or cardiac arrest, and may require further management with anticoagulation therapy.
4. **Thrombocytopenia:** The patient's thrombocytopenia may increase the risk of bleeding, particularly if she undergoes invasive procedures or receives anticoagulant therapy.
5. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not properly managed, leading to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis.
6. **Kidney Injury:** The patient's renal cancer and potential kidney injury from septic shock and volume overload may worsen her renal function and increase the risk of acute kidney injury.
7. **Dementia:** The patient's dementia may complicate her care, particularly if she requires sedation or other medications that may exacerbate her cognitive impairment.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   85yo F with a h/o choledocholithiasis, HTN, renal CA, and dementia who
   presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory
   failure and septic shock likely secondary to cholangitis. She is s/p
   ERCP and stent.
   .
   # Dyspnea/respiratory failure: Resp failure does not appear [**3-13**] primary
   lung process, as CXR is rather unimpressive, but in the setting of her
   metabolic acidosis she was hyperventilating to compensate and
   fatigued. Becoming acutely SOB and requiring intubation in the ED.
   Unable to wean effectively; likely secondary to fluid resuscitation; as
   fluid overload is seen on CXR.
   - Monitor UOP as patient is auto-diuresing well. Check i/o
s this
   evening with TBB 1-1.5 liters, if not at goal will trial some lasix if
   her blood pressure can tolerate
   - Wean down vent settings as much as possible, but having difficulty
   due to volume overload
   - CXR tomorrow morning to evaluate for improvement in volume overload
   - will further clarify intubation status with family prior to
   extubation, to see if they would want her to be re-intubated if she has
   difficulty post extubation
   # Atrial Fibrillation: First occurred during SBT on [**11-23**], initially
   rates were in the 110
s, then increased to the 130
s.  Patient has
   remained tachycardic on amio gtt, now that she is off pressors will
   trial a low dose beta blocker,
   - Metoprolol 5mg IV: monitor effect on HR and BP, has been on
   metoprolol at home
   # Septic shock:  Likely secondary to cholangitis and infected
   stone/sludge. ERCP showed significant pusand very large stone, she is
   s/p stent placement. Patient afebrile and white count trending down.
   Lactate now normal. Initial sepsis likely secondary to biliary source
   given CBD dilation with sludge and obstructive LFTs in setting on known
   choledocholithiasis. No other source of infection found.
   - Leukocytosis is resolving
white count almost normalized, has been
   afebrile for over 24hours
   - Cont zosyn pending any further culture data; Day [**6-18**] of zosyn. Day
   1: [**11-22**].  Will f/u cutlure data to see if we can narrow our coverage,
   if she needs to be continued on Zosyn will place a PICC and pull
   central line
   - LFT
s normalized, no longer need to trend daily
   - plan for repeat ERCP in one month, after resolution of initial
   infection for stone break up and removal
   .
   # ARF: Improved, near baseline. Likely related to sepsis and
   intravascular volume depletion secondary to vomiting and diarrhea, also
   likely some component of ATN as her renal function has not improved as
   quickly with fluids as would be expected in a purely pre-renal picture.
   Cr improving to 1.5 today, baseline creatinine 1.2-1.4.
   - Monitor UOP
   - Trend creatinine
   .
   #Thrombocytopenia: Stable, and her platelet count is increasing. Likely
   secondary to sepsis.
   - Will restart SQ heparin as her platelet count has increased and the
   initial drop was not consistent with HIT
   - No signs of active bleeding
